{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} The '''HP threats from cosmic rays''' is the danger posed by [[galactic cosmic rays]] (GCR) and [[solar energetic particles]] to astronauts on [[interplanetary mission]]s or any missions that venture through the [[Van Allen radiation belt|Van-Allen Belts]] or outside the [[Earth's magnetosphere]].<ref name="THREE - Space Radiation Introduction">{{cite web|last=Schimmerling|first=Walter|title=The Space Radiation Environment: An Introduction|url=http://three.usra.edu/concepts/SpaceRadiationEnviron.pdf|work=The Health Risks of Extraterrestrial Environments|publisher=Universities Space Research Association Division of Space Life Sciences|accessdate=5 December 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120426022341/http://three.usra.edu/concepts/SpaceRadiationEnviron.pdf|archivedate=26 April 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="NYT-20140127">{{cite news |last=Chang |first=Kenneth |title=Beings Not Made for Space |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/01/28/science/bodies-not-made-for-space.html |date=27 January 2014 |work=[[New York Times]] |accessdate=27 January 2014 }}</ref> They are one of the greatest barriers standing in the way of plans for interplanetary travel by [[human spaceflight|crewed spacecraft]],<ref name="WIRED-20140212">{{cite web |last=Fong, MD |first=Kevin |title=The Strange, Deadly Effects Mars Would Have on Your Body |url=https://www.wired.com/opinion/2014/02/happens-body-mars/ |date=12 February 2014|work=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] |accessdate=12 February 2014 }}</ref><ref name="nasa">{{cite web|url=https://science.nasa.gov/headlines/y2004/17feb_radiation.htm|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040219011918/http://science.nasa.gov/headlines/y2004/17feb_radiation.htm|dead-url=yes|archive-date=19 February 2004|publisher=science.nasa.gov|title=Can People go to Mars?|accessdate=2 April 2017}}</ref><ref> {{Citation | last = Shiga | first = David | title = Too much radiation for astronauts to make it to Mars | journal = [[New Scientist]] | issue = 2726 | date = 16 September 2009 | url = https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg20327266.100-too-much-radiation-for-astronauts-to-make-it-to-mars.html }} </ref> but space radiation health risks also occur for missions in low Earth orbit such as the International Space Station (ISS).<ref>{{cite book | last = Virts | first = Terry | author-link = Terry W. Virts | title = View From Above: An Astronaut Photographs The World | publisher = National Geographic | year = 2017 | page = 101 | isbn = 9781426218644 | quote = Whenever the ISS flew through the [[South Atlantic Anomaly]], we were exposed to a much greater flux of [galactic cosmic radiation].}}</ref>
In October 2015, the [[NASA Office of Inspector General]] issued a [[Effect of spaceflight on the human body|health hazards report]] related to [[Human spaceflight|space exploration]], including a [[human mission to Mars|human mission]] to [[Mars]].<ref name="AP-20151029">{{cite news |last=Dunn |first=Marcia |title=Report: NASA needs better handle on health hazards for Mars |url=http://apnews.excite.com/article/20151029/us-sci-space-travel-health-6dfd5b2c76.html |date=29 October 2015 |work=[[AP News]] |accessdate=30 October 2015 }}</ref><ref name="NASA-20151029oig">{{cite web |author=Staff |title=NASA's Efforts to Manage Health and Human Performance Risks for Space Exploration (IG-16-003) |url=https://oig.nasa.gov/audits/reports/FY16/IG-16-003.pdf |format=[[PDF]] |date=29 October 2015 |work=[[NASA]] |accessdate=29 October 2015 }}</ref>
==The deep-space radiation environment== [[File:PIA16938-RadiationSources-InterplanetarySpace.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Sources of ionizing radiation in interplanetary space.]] The radiation environment of deep space is different from that on the Earth's surface or in [[low Earth orbit]], due to the much larger flux of high-energy galactic cosmic rays (GCRs), along with radiation from [[solar proton event]]s (SPEs) and the [[radiation belt]]s.
Galactic cosmic rays (GCRs) consist of high energy [[proton]]s (85%), helium (14%) and other high energy [[Atomic nucleus|nuclei]] ([[HZE ions]]).<ref name="THREE - Space Radiation Introduction" /> Solar energetic particles consist primarily of protons accelerated by the Sun to high energies via proximity to [[solar flares]] and [[coronal mass ejections]]. Heavy ions and low energy protons and helium particles are highly ionizing forms of radiation, which produce distinct biological damage compared to X-rays and gamma-rays. Microscopic energy deposition from highly ionizing particles consists of a core radiation track due to direct ionizations by the particle and low energy electrons produced in ionization, and a penumbra of higher energy electrons that may extend hundreds of microns from the particles path in tissue. The core track produces extremely large clusters of ionizations within a few [[nanometre]]s, which is qualitatively distinct from energy deposition by [[X-rays]] and [[gamma ray]]s; hence human epidemiology data which only exists for these latter forms of radiation is limited in predicting the health risks from space radiation to astronauts.
But of course the radiation belts are within Earth’s magnetosphere and do not occur in deep space, while organ dose equivalents on the International Space Station are dominated by GCR not trapped radiation. Microscopic energy deposition in cells and tissues is distinct for GCR compared to X-rays on Earth leading to both qualitative and quantitative differences in biological effects, while there is no human epidemiology data for GCR for cancer and other fatal risks.
The solar cycle is an approximately 11-year period of varying solar activity including solar maximum where the solar wind is strongest and solar minimum where the solar wind is weakest. Galactic cosmic rays create a continuous radiation dose throughout the [[Solar System]] that increases during solar minimum and decreases during solar maximum ([[Solar variation|solar activity]]). The inner and outer radiation belts are two regions of trapped particles from the solar wind that are later accelerated by dynamic interaction with the Earth's magnetic field. While always high, the radiation dose in these belts can increase dramatically during [[geomagnetic storms]] and [[substorm]]s. Solar proton events (SPEs) are bursts of energetic protons accelerated by the Sun. They occur relatively rarely and can produce extremely high radiation levels. Without thick shielding, SPEs are sufficiently strong to cause acute [[radiation poisoning]] and death.<ref name="nasa2">{{cite web|url=http://lsda.jsc.nasa.gov/books/apollo/S2ch3.htm|publisher=lsda.jsc.nasa.gov|title=Biomedical Results From Apollo - Radiation Protection and Instrumentation|accessdate=2 April 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130515020144/http://lsda.jsc.nasa.gov/books/apollo/S2ch3.htm|archivedate=15 May 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Life on the Earth's surface is protected from galactic cosmic rays by a number of factors: # The Earth's atmosphere is opaque to primary cosmic rays with energies below about 1 gigaelectron volt (GeV), so only secondary radiation can reach the surface. The secondary radiation is also attenuated by absorption in the atmosphere, as well as by radioactive decay in flight of some particles, such as muons. Particles entering from a direction far from the zenith are especially attenuated. The world's population receives an average of 0.4 milli[[sievert]]s (mSv) of cosmic radiation annually (separate from other sources of radiation exposure like inhaled radon) due to atmospheric shielding. At 12 km altitude, above most of the [[atmosphere of Earth|atmosphere's]] protection, radiation as an annual rate rises to 20 mSv at the equator to 50–120 mSv at the poles, varying between solar maximum and minimum conditions.<ref>[http://cordis.europa.eu/documents/documentlibrary/75331981EN6.pdf Evaluation of the Cosmic Ray Exposure of Aircraft Crew]</ref><ref>[http://www.unscear.org/docs/reports/2008/09-86753_Report_2008_GA_Report_corr2.pdf Sources and Effects of Ionizing Radiation, UNSCEAR 2008]</ref><ref>{{cite web| last =Phillips| first =Tony| title =The Effects of Space Weather on Aviation| work =Science News| publisher =NASA| date =25 October 2013| url =https://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2013/25oct_aviationswx/}}</ref> # Missions beyond low Earth orbit transit the [[Van Allen radiation belt]]s. Thus they may need to be shielded against exposure to cosmic rays, Van Allen radiation, or solar flares. The region between two and four Earth radii lies between the two radiation belts and is sometimes referred to as the "safe zone".<ref>{{cite web | title=Earth's Radiation Belts with Safe Zone Orbit | publisher=Goddard Space Flight Center, NASA | url=http://svs.gsfc.nasa.gov/vis/a000000/a003000/a003052/index.html | accessdate=27 April 2009 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | first=Rachel A. | last=Weintraub | title=Earth's Safe Zone Became Hot Zone During Legendary Solar Storms | publisher=Goddard Space Flight Center, NASA | url=http://www.nasa.gov/vision/universe/solarsystem/safe_zone.html | accessdate=27 April 2009 }}</ref> See the [[Van Allen radiation belt#Implications for space travel|implications of the Van Allen belts for space travel]] for more information. # The [[interplanetary magnetic field]], embedded in the [[solar wind]], also deflects cosmic rays. As a result, cosmic ray fluxes within the [[heliopause (astronomy)|heliopause]] are inversely correlated with the [[solar cycle]].<ref>{{cite journal| last =Schwadron| first =N.| title =Does the worsening galactic cosmic radiation environment observed by CRaTER preclude future manned deep space exploration?| journal =Space Weather| publisher =AGU| date =8 November 2014| url =http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/enhanced/doi/10.1002/2014SW001084/| doi =10.1002/2014SW001084| accessdate =6 December 2014| volume=12| issue =11| pages=622–632| bibcode =2014SpWea..12..622S}}</ref> # [[Electromagnetic radiation]] created by lightning in clouds only a few miles high can create a safe zone in the [[Van Allen radiation belt]]s that surround the earth. This zone, known as the "Van Allen Belt slot", may be a safe haven for [[satellite]]s in [[medium Earth orbit]]s (MEOs), protecting them from the Sun's intense [[Solar radiation|radiation]].<ref name="flashes">{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/vision/universe/solarsystem/image_lightning.html|title=Flashes in the Sky: Lightning Zaps Space Radiation Surrounding Earth|accessdate=September 24, 2007|publisher=[[NASA]]|year=2005|author=NASA|authorlink=NASA}}</ref><ref name="space1">{{cite web|url=http://www.space.com/scienceastronomy/planetearth/space_lightning_991216.html |title=Lightning Interacts with Space, Electrons Rain Down |accessdate=September 24, 2007 |publisher=Space.com |year=1999 |author=Robert Roy Britt |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100812223630/http://www.space.com/scienceastronomy/planetearth/space_lightning_991216.html |archivedate=August 12, 2010 }}</ref><ref name="demirkol"> {{cite journal | last =Demirkol | first =M. K. |author2=Inan, Umran S. |author3=Bell, T.F. |author4=Kanekal, S.G. |author5= Wilkinson, D.C. | title =Ionospheric effects of relativistic electron enhancement events | journal =Geophysical Research Letters | volume = 26 | issue = 23 | pages =3557–3560 | year =1999 | bibcode =1999GeoRL..26.3557D | doi = 10.1029/1999GL010686}}</ref>
As a result, the energy input of GCRs to the atmosphere is negligible – about 10<sup>−9</sup> of [[solar radiation]] – roughly the same as starlight.<ref name=CRC>Jasper Kirkby; [https://arxiv.org/abs/0804.1938v1 Cosmic Rays And Climate] CERN-PH-EP/2008-005 26 March 2008</ref>
Of the above factors, all but the first one apply to [[low Earth orbit]] craft, such as the [[Space Shuttle]] and the [[International Space Station]]. Exposures on the [[International Space Station|ISS]] average 150 mSv per year, although frequent crew rotations minimize individual risk.<ref name = historicalexposure>[https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/20070010704_2007005310.pdf Space Radiation Organ Doses for Astronauts on Past and Future Missions] Table 4</ref> Astronauts on [[Project Apollo|Apollo]] and [[Skylab]] missions received on average 1.2 mSv/day and 1.4 mSv/day respectively.<ref name = historicalexposure/> Since the durations of the Apollo and Skylab missions were days and months, respectively, rather than years, the doses involved were smaller than would be expected on future long-term missions such as to a near-Earth asteroid or to Mars<ref name="WIRED-20140212" /> (unless far more shielding could be provided).
On 31 May 2013, NASA scientists reported that a possible [[manned mission to Mars]]<ref name="WIRED-20140212" /> may involve a great [[radiation|radiation risk]] based on the amount of [[radiation|energetic particle radiation]] detected by the [[radiation assessment detector]] (RAD) on the [[Mars Science Laboratory]] while traveling from the [[Earth]] to [[Mars]] in 2011–2012.<ref name="SCI-20130531a" /><ref name="SCI-20130531b" /><ref name="NYT-20130530" /> However, the absorbed dose and dose equivalent for a Mars mission were predicted in the early 1990s by Badhwar, Cucinotta, and others (see for example Badhwar, Cucinotta et al., Radiation Research vol. 138, 201-208, 1994) and the result of the MSL experiment are to a large extent consistent with these earlier predictions.
==Human health effects== [[File:PIA17601-Comparisons-RadiationExposure-MarsTrip-20131209.png|thumb|250px|left| Comparison of radiation doses, includes the amount detected on the trip from Earth to Mars by the RAD on the MSL (2011–2013).<ref name="SCI-20130531a">{{cite journal |last=Kerr|first=Richard|title=Radiation Will Make Astronauts' Trip to Mars Even Riskier|url=http://www.sciencemag.org/content/340/6136/1031.summary |date=31 May 2013 |journal=[[Science (journal)|Science]] |volume=340 |issue=6136|page=1031 |doi=10.1126/science.340.6136.1031 |accessdate=31 May 2013 |pmid=23723213}}</ref><ref name="SCI-20130531b">{{cite journal |author=Zeitlin, C. |display-authors=etal |title=Measurements of Energetic Particle Radiation in Transit to Mars on the Mars Science Laboratory|url=http://www.sciencemag.org/content/340/6136/1080.abstract |journal=[[Science (journal)|Science]]|date=31 May 2013 |volume=340 |issue=6136 |pages=1080–1084 |doi=10.1126/science.1235989 |accessdate=31 May 2013|bibcode=2013Sci...340.1080Z }}</ref><ref name="NYT-20130530">{{cite news |last=Chang |first=Kenneth |title=Data Point to Radiation Risk for Travelers to Mars|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/05/31/science/space/data-show-higher-cancer-risk-for-mars-astronauts.html|date=30 May 2013 |publisher=[[New York Times]] |accessdate=31 May 2013 }}</ref> The y-axis scale is in [[logarithmic scale]]. For example, the exposure from 6 months aboard the ISS is roughly a factor of 10 greater than that from an abdominal CT scan.]] The potential acute and chronic health effects of space radiation, as with other ionizing radiation exposures, involve both direct damage to DNA, indirect effects due to generation of reactive oxygen species, and changes to the biochemistry of cells and tissues, which can alter gene transcription and the tissue microenvironment along with producing DNA mutations. Acute (or early radiation) effects result from high radiation doses, and these are most likely to occur after solar particle events (SPEs).<ref name="THREE - Acute Effects">{{cite web|last=Seed|first=Thomas|title=Acute Effects|url=http://three.usra.edu/articles/SeedAcuteEffects.pdf|work=The Health Effects of Extraterrestrial Environments|publisher=Universities Space Research Association, Division of Space Life Sciences|accessdate=5 December 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120426022353/http://three.usra.edu/articles/SeedAcuteEffects.pdf|archivedate=26 April 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Likely chronic effects of space radiation exposure include both stochastic events such as radiation [[carcinogenesis]]<ref>{{cite journal|last=Cucinotta|first=F.A.|author2=Durante, M.|title=Cancer risk from exposure to galactic cosmic rays: implications for space exploration by human beings|journal=Lancet Oncol.|date=2006|volume=7|pages=431–435|doi=10.1016/S1470-2045(06)70695-7|pmid=16648048|issue=5}}</ref> and deterministic degenerative tissue effects. To date, however, the only pathology associated with space radiation exposure is a higher risk for [[Cataract#Radiation|radiation cataract]] among the astronaut corps.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Cucinotta|first=F.A.|author2=Manuel, F.K. |author3=Jones, J. |author4=Iszard, G. |author5=Murrey, J. |author6=Djojonegro, B. |author7=Wear, M. |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Space radiation and cataracts in astronauts|journal=Rad. Res.|date=2001|volume=156|issue=5|pages=460–466|doi=10.1667/0033-7587(2001)156[0460:sracia]2.0.co;2|bibcode=2001RadR..156..460C}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Rastegar|first=Z.N. |author2=Eckart, P. |author3=Mertz, M. |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Radiation cataracts in astronauts and cosmonauts|journal=Graefe. Arch. Clin. Exp. Ophthalmol|date=2002|volume=240|issue=7 |pages=543–547|doi=10.1007/s00417-002-0489-4}}</ref>
The health threat depends on the flux, energy spectrum, and nuclear composition of the radiation. The flux and energy spectrum depend on a variety of factors: short-term solar weather, long-term trends (such as an apparent increase since the 1950s<ref name="icrc2005.tifr.res.in">{{cite web|title=The Cosmic Ray Radiation Dose in Interplanetary Space – Present Day and Worst-Case Evaluations |date=2005-08-03<!--date of Pune conference start--> |accessdate=8 March 2008 |author=R.A. Mewaldt |url=http://www.srl.caltech.edu/ACE/ASC/DATA/bibliography/ICRC2005/usa-mewaldt-RA-abs1-sh35-oral.pdf |pages=103 |location=29th [[International Cosmic Ray Conference]] Pune (2005) 00, 101-104|display-authors=etal}}</ref>), and position in the Sun's magnetic field. These factors are incompletely understood.<ref>{{cite journal | author=John Dudley Miller |title=Radiation Redux | journal=Scientific American | date=November 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nap.edu/catalog.php?record_id=11760 |title=Space Radiation Hazards and the Vision for Space Exploration |author=Space Studies Board and Division on Engineering and Physical Sciences, National Academy of Sciences|publisher=NAP |date=2006}}</ref> The [[Mars Radiation Environment Experiment]] (MARIE) was launched in 2001 in order to collect more data. Estimates are that humans unshielded in interplanetary space would receive annually roughly 400 to 900 mSv (compared to 2.4 mSv on Earth) and that a Mars mission (12 months in flight and 18 months on Mars) might expose shielded astronauts to roughly 500 to 1000 mSv.<ref name="icrc2005.tifr.res.in"/> These doses approach the 1 to 4 Sv career limits advised by the [[National Council on Radiation Protection and Measurements]] (NCRP) for [[low Earth orbit]] activities in 1989, and the more recent NCRP recommendations of 0.5 to 2 Sv in 2000 based on updated information on dose to risk conversion factors. Dose limits depend on age at exposure and sex due to difference in [[Susceptible individual|susceptibility]] with age, the added risks of [[breast cancer|breast]] and [[ovarian cancer]]s to women, and the variability of cancer risks such as [[lung cancer]] between men and women.
The quantitative biological effects of cosmic rays are poorly known, and are the subject of ongoing research. Several experiments, both in space and on Earth, are being carried out to evaluate the exact degree of danger. Additionally, the impact of the space microgravity environment on DNA repair has in part confounded the interpretation of some results.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Moreno-Villanueva|first=M.|author2=Wong, M. |author3=Lu, T. |author4=Zhang, Y. |author5=Wu, H. |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Interplay of space radiation and microgravity in DNA damage and DNA damage response| journal=Npj Microgravity |date=2017|volume=3|issue=14|doi=10.1038/s41526-017-0019-7}}</ref> Experiments over the last 10 years have shown results both higher and lower than predicted by current quality factors used in radiation protection, indicating large uncertainties exist. Experiments in 2007 at [[Brookhaven National Laboratory]]'s [[NASA Space Radiation Laboratory]] (NSRL) suggest that biological damage due to a given exposure is actually about half what was previously estimated: specifically, it turns out that low energy protons cause more damage than high energy ones.<ref>{{cite journal | journal=Radiat Environ Biophys |date=Jun 2007 | volume=46 |issue=2 | pages=119–23 | pmid=17256176 | title=Split-dose exposures versus dual ion exposure in human cell neoplastic transformation |vauthors=Bennett PV, Cutter NC, Sutherland BM | doi=10.1007/s00411-006-0091-y}}</ref> This is explained by the fact that slower particles have more time to interact with molecules in the body. This may be interpreted as an acceptable result for space travel as the cells affected end up with greater energy deposition and are more likely to die without proliferating into tumors. This is in contrast to the current dogma on radiation exposure to human cells which considers lower energy radiation of higher weighting factor for tumor formation. Relative biological effectiveness (RBE) depends on radiation type described by particle charge number, Z, and kinetic energy per amu, E, and varies with tumor type with limited experimental data suggesting [[leukemia]]'s having the lowest RBE, liver tumors the highest RBE, and limited or no experimental data on RBE available for cancers that dominate human cancer risks including lung, stomach, breast, and [[bladder cancer]]s. Studies of Harderian gland tumors in a single strain of female mice with several heavy ions have been made, however it is not clear how well the RBE for this tumor type represents the RBE for human cancers such as lung, stomach, breast and bladder cancers nor how RBE changes with sex and genetic background.
Part of the [[ISS year long mission]] is to determine the health impacts of cosmic ray exposure over the course of one year spent aboard the [[International Space Station]].
However, [[sample size]]s for accurately estimating health risks directly from crew observations for the risks of concern (cancer, cataracts, cognitive and memory changes, late CNS risks, circulatory diseases, etc.) are large (typically >>10 persons) and necessarily involve long post-mission observation times (>10 years). It will be difficult for a sufficient number of astronauts to occupy the ISS and for the missions to continue long enough to make an impact on risk predictions for late effects due to statistical limitations. Hence the need for ground-based research to predict cosmic ray health risks. In addition, radiation safety requirements mandate that risks should be adequately understood prior to astronauts incurring significant risks, and methods developed to mitigate the risks if necessary.
In September 2017, NASA reported [[Radiation|radiation levels]] on the surface of the planet [[Mars]] were temporarily [[Orders of magnitude (radiation)|doubled]], and were associated with an [[aurora]] 25-times brighter than any observed earlier, due to a massive, and unexpected, [[Coronal mass ejection|solar storm]] in the middle of the month.<ref name="PHYS-20170930">{{cite web |last=Scott |first=Jim |title=Large solar storm sparks global aurora and doubles radiation levels on the martian surface |url=https://phys.org/news/2017-09-large-solar-storm-global-aurora.html |date=30 September 2017 |work=[[Phys.org]] |accessdate=30 September 2017 }}</ref>
=== Central nervous system === {{see also|Central nervous system effects from radiation exposure during spaceflight}} Hypothetical early and late effects on the central nervous system are of great concern to NASA and an area of active current research interest. It is postulated short- and long-term effects of CNS exposure to galactic cosmic radiation are likely to pose significant neurological health risks to human long-term space travel.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Vazquez|first=M.E.|title=Neurobiological problems in long-term deep space flights|journal=Adv. Space Res.|date=1998|volume=22|issue=2|pages=171–173|bibcode = 1998AdSpR..22..171V |doi = 10.1016/S0273-1177(98)80009-4 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Blakely|first=E.A.|author2=Chang, P.Y.|title=A review of ground-based heavy ion radiobiology relevant to space radiation risk assessment: Cataracts and CNS effects|journal=Adv. Space Res.|date=2007|volume=40|issue=9|pages=1307–1319|bibcode = 2007AdSpR..40.1307B |doi = 10.1016/j.asr.2007.03.070 }}</ref> Estimates suggest considerable exposure to high energy heavy (HZE) ions as well as protons and secondary radiation during Mars or prolonged Lunar missions with estimates of whole body effective doses ranging from 0.17 to greater than 1.0 Sv.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Hellweg|first=CE|author2=Baumstark-Kahn, C |title=Getting ready for the manned mission to Mars: the astronauts' risk from space radiation |journal=Naturwissenschaften|date=2007|volume=94|issue=7|pages=517–519|bibcode = 2007NW.....94..517H |doi = 10.1007/s00114-006-0204-0 |pmid=17235598}}</ref> Given the high [[linear energy transfer]] potential of such particles, a considerable proportion of those cells exposed to HZE radiation are likely to die. Based on calculations of heavy ion fluences during space flight as well as various experimental cell models, as many as 5% of an astronaut’s cells might be killed during such missions.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Badwhar|first=G.D.|author2=Nachtwey, D.S. |author3=Yang, T.C.-H. |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Radiation issues for piloted Mars mission|journal=Adv. Space Res.|date=1992|volume=12|issue=2–3|pages=195–200|bibcode=1992AdSpR..12R.195B|doi=10.1016/0273-1177(92)90108-A|pmid=11537008}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Cucinotta|first=F.A.|author2=Nikjoo, H. |author3=Goodhead, D.T. |lastauthoramp=yes |title=The effects of delta rays on the number of particle-track traversals per cell in laboratory and space exposures|journal=Radiat. Res.|date=1988|volume=150|pages=115–119}}</ref> With respect to cells in critical [[brain regions]], as many as 13% of such cells may be traversed at least once by an iron ion during a three-year Mars mission.<ref name="WIRED-20140212" /><ref>{{cite journal|last=Curtis|first=S.B.|author2=Vazquez, M.E. |author3=Wilson, J.W. |author4=Atwell, W. |author5=Kim, M. |author6=Capala, J. |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Cosmic ray hit frequencies in critical sites in the central nervous system|journal=Adv. Space Res.|date=1988|volume=22|issue=2|pages=197–207.|bibcode=1998AdSpR..22..197C|doi=10.1016/S0273-1177(98)80011-2|pmid=11541397}}</ref> Several [[Apollo program|Apollo]] astronauts reported seeing light [[Cosmic ray visual phenomena|flashes]], although the precise biological mechanisms responsible are unclear. Likely pathways include heavy ion interactions with [[retina|retinal photoreceptors]]<ref>{{cite journal|last=Pinsky|first=L.S.|author2=Osborne, W.Z. |author3=Bailey, J.V. |author4=Benson, R.E. |author5=Thompson, L.F. |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Light flashes observed by astronauts on Apollo 11 through Apollo 17|journal=Science|volume=183|pages=957–959.|doi=10.1126/science.183.4128.957|issue=4128|year=1974|bibcode=1974Sci...183..957P}}</ref> and [[Cherenkov radiation]] resulting from particle interactions within the [[vitreous humor]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=McNulty|first=P.J.|author2=Pease, V.P. |author3=Bond, V.P. |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Visual Sensations Induced by Cerenkov Radiation|journal=Science|date=1975|volume=189|issue=4201|pages=453–454|bibcode = 1975Sci...189..453M |doi = 10.1126/science.1154020 }}</ref> This phenomenon has been replicated on Earth by scientists at various institutions.<ref>{{cite journal|last=McNulty|first=P.J. |author2=Pease, V.P. |author3=Bond, V.P. |title=Comparison of the light-flash phenomena observed in space and in laboratory experiments|journal=Life Sci. Space Res.|date=1977|volume=15|pages=135–140|doi=10.2172/7312082}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Tobias|first=C.A. |author2=Budinger, T.F. |author3=Lyman, J.T. |title=Biological effects due to single accelerated heavy particles and the problems of nervous system exposure in space|journal=Life Sci. Space Res.|date=1973|volume=11|pages=233–245|doi=10.2172/4617388}}</ref> As the duration of the longest Apollo flights was less than two weeks, the astronauts had limited cumulative exposures and a corresponding low risk for radiation [[carcinogenesis]]. In addition, there were only 24 such astronauts, making [[statistical analysis]] of any potential health effects problematic.
In the above discussion dose equivalents is units of Sievert (Sv) are noted, however the Sv is a unit for comparing cancer risks for different types of ionizing radiation. For CNS effects absorbed doses in Gy are more useful, while the RBE for CNS effects is poorly understood. Furthermore, stating "hypothetical" risk is problematic, while space radiation CNS risk estimates have largely focused on early and late detriments to memory and cognition (e.g. Cucinotta, Alp, Sulzman, and Wang, Life Sciences in Space Research, 2014).
On 31 December 2012, a [[NASA]]-supported study reported that manned spaceflight may harm the brains of astronauts and accelerate the onset of [[Alzheimer's disease]].<ref name="PLOS-20121231">{{cite journal |last=Cherry |first=Jonathan D. |last2=Frost |first2=Jeffrey L. |last3=Lemere |first3=Cynthia A. |last4=Williams |first4=Jacqueline P. |last5=Olschowka |first5=John A. |last6=O'Banion |first6=M. Kerry |title=Galactic Cosmic Radiation Leads to Cognitive Impairment and Increased Aβ Plaque Accumulation in a Mouse Model of Alzheimer's Disease |url=http://www.plosone.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pone.0053275 |doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0053275 |volume=7 |issue=12 |page=e53275 |journal=[[PLoS ONE]] |accessdate=7 January 2013 |bibcode = 2012PLoSO...753275C |pmid=23300905 |pmc=3534034|year=2012 }}</ref><ref name="spaceref">{{cite web |author=Staff |title=Study Shows that Space Travel is Harmful to the Brain and Could Accelerate Onset of Alzheimer's |url=http://spaceref.com/news/viewpr.html?pid=39650 |date=1 January 2013 |publisher=SpaceRef |accessdate=7 January 2013 }}</ref><ref name="NasaWatch-20130103">{{cite web |last=Cowing |first=Keith |authorlink=Keith Cowing |title=Important Research Results NASA Is Not Talking About (Update) |url=http://nasawatch.com/archives/2013/01/important-resea.html |date=3 January 2013 |publisher=NASA Watch |accessdate=7 January 2013 }}</ref> This research is problematic due to many factors, inclusive of the intensity of which mice were exposed to radiation which far exceeds normal mission rates.
A review of CNS space radiobiology by Cucinotta, Alp, Sulzman, and Wang (Life Sciences in Space Research, 2014) summarizes research studies in small animals of changes to cognition and memory, neuro-inflammation, neuron morphology, and impaired neurogenesis in the hippocampus. Studies using simulated space radiation in small animals suggest temporary or long-term cognitive detriments could occur during a long-term space mission. Changes to neuron morphology in mouse hippocampus and pre-frontal cortex occur for heavy ions at low doses (<0.3 Gy). Studies in mice and rats of chronic neuro-inflammation and behavioral changes show variable results at low doses (~0.1 Gy or lower). Further research is needed to understand if such cognitive detriments induced by space radiation would occur in astronauts and whether they would negatively impact a Mars mission.
The cumulative heavy ion doses in space are low such that critical cells and cell components will receive only 0 or 1 particle traversal. The cumulative heavy ion dose for a Mars mission near solar minimum would be ~0.05 Gy and lower for missions at other times in the solar cycle. This suggests dose-rate effects will not occur for heavy ions as long as the total doses used in experimental studies in reasonably small (<~0.1 Gy). At larger doses (>~0.1 Gy) critical cells and cell components could receive more than one particle traversal, which is not reflective of the deep space environment for extended duration missions such as a mission to Mars. An alternative assumption would be if a tissues micro-environment is modified by a long-range signaling effect or change to biochemistry, whereby a particle traversal to some cells modifies the response of other cells not traversed by particles. There is limited experimental evidence, especially for central nervous system effects, available to evaluate this alternative assumption.
==Prevention==
===Shielding=== [[File:Cosmic ray shielding with secondary radiation.jpg|thumb|Standard spacecraft shielding, integrated into hull design, is strong protection from most solar radiation, but defeats this purpose with high-energy cosmic rays, as it simply splits this into showers of secondary particles. This shower of secondary and fragmented particles may be reduced by the use of hydrogen or light elements for shielding.]] Material shielding can be effective against galactic cosmic rays, but thin shielding may actually make the problem worse for some of the higher energy rays, because more shielding causes an increased amount of [[Bremsstrahlung|secondary radiation]], although thick shielding could counter such too.<ref name = mass_shielding>NASA SP-413 [http://settlement.arc.nasa.gov/75SummerStudy/5appendE.html Space Settlements: A Design Study. Appendix E Mass Shielding] Retrieved 3 May 2011.</ref> The aluminium walls of the ISS, for example, are believed to produce a net reduction in radiation exposure. In interplanetary space, however, it is believed that thin aluminium shielding would give a net increase in radiation exposure but would gradually decrease as more shielding is added to capture generated secondary radiation.<ref name="islandone.org">{{cite web | url=http://www.islandone.org/Settlements/MagShield.html | title=Magnetic Radiation Shielding: An Idea Whose Time Has Returned? | author=G.Landis |date=1991}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | journal=Popular Science | title=Juno Probe, Built to Study Jupiter's Radiation Belt, Gets A Titanium Suit of Interplanetary Armor | author=Rebecca Boyle | date=13 July 2010 | url=http://www.popsci.com/science/article/2010-07/juno-probe-built-study-jupiters-radiation-belt-gets-coat-armor}}</ref>
Studies of space radiation shielding should include tissue or water equivalent shielding along with the shielding material under study. This observation is readily understood by noting that the average tissue self-shielding of sensitive organs is about 10 cm, and that secondary radiation produced in tissue such as low energy protons, helium and heavy ions are of high [[Linear_energy_transfer|linear energy transfer]] (LET) and make significant contributions (>25%) to the overall biological damage from GCR. Studies of aluminum, polyethylene, liquid hydrogen, or other shielding materials, will involve secondary radiation not reflective of secondary radiation produced in tissue, hence the need to include tissue equivalent shielding in studies of space radiation shielding effectiveness.
Several strategies are being studied for ameliorating the effects of this radiation hazard for planned human interplanetary spaceflight: * Spacecraft can be constructed out of hydrogen-rich plastics, rather than aluminium.<ref name="nasa3">{{cite web|url=https://science.nasa.gov/headlines/y2005/25aug_plasticspaceships.htm|publisher=science.nasa.gov|title=NASA - Plastic Spaceships|accessdate=2 April 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100323201842/http://science.nasa.gov/headlines/y2005/25aug_plasticspaceships.htm|archivedate=23 March 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref> * Material shielding has been considered: ** Liquid hydrogen, which would be brought along as fuel in any case, tends to give relatively good shielding, while producing relatively low levels of secondary radiation. Therefore, the fuel could be placed so as to act as a form of shielding around the crew. However, as fuel is consumed by the craft, the crew's shielding decreases. ** Water, which is necessary to sustain life, could also contribute to shielding. But it too is consumed during the journey unless waste products are utilized.<ref name = newscientist>{{cite web|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article.ns?id=dn7753|publisher=New Scientist|title= Cosmic rays may prevent long-haul space travel|date= 1 August 2005 |accessdate=2 April 2017}}</ref> ** Asteroids could serve to provide shielding.<ref>Morgan, P. (2011) [http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/discoblog/2011/02/11/to-hitch-a-ride-to-mars-just-flag-down-an-asteroid/ "To Hitch a Ride to Mars, Just Flag Down an Asteroid"] ''Discover'' magazine blog</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author1=Matloff G.L. |author2=Wilga M. | date = 2011 | title = NEOs as stepping stones to Mars and main-belt asteroids | doi = 10.1016/j.actaastro.2010.02.026 | journal = Acta Astronautica | volume = 68 | issue = 5–6| pages = 599–602 |bibcode=2011AcAau..68..599M }}</ref> * Magnetic deflection of charged radiation particles and/or electrostatic repulsion is a hypothetical alternative to pure conventional mass shielding under investigation. In theory, power requirements for a 5-meter torus drop from an excessive 10 [[Gigawatt|GW]] for a simple pure electrostatic shield (too discharged by space electrons) to a moderate 10 [[kilowatt]]s (kW) by using a hybrid design.<ref name="islandone.org"/> However, such complex active shielding is untried, with workability and practicalities more uncertain than material shielding.<ref name="islandone.org"/>
Special provisions would also be necessary to protect against a solar proton event, which could increase fluxes to levels that would kill a crew in hours or days rather than months or years. Potential mitigation strategies include providing a small habitable space behind a spacecraft's water supply or with particularly thick walls or providing an option to abort to the protective environment provided by the Earth's magnetosphere. The Apollo mission used a combination of both strategies. Upon receiving confirmation of an SPE, astronauts would move to the Command Module, which had thicker aluminium walls than the Lunar Module, then return to Earth. It was later determined from measurements taken by instruments flown on Apollo that the Command Module would have provided sufficient shielding to prevent significant crew harm.{{Citation needed|date=April 2010}}
None of these strategies currently provide a method of protection that would be known to be sufficient<ref name="parker" /> while conforming to likely limitations on the mass of the payload at present (around $10,000/kg) launch prices. Scientists such as University of Chicago professor emeritus Eugene Parker are not optimistic it can be solved anytime soon.<ref name="parker">{{cite journal | author=Eugene N. Parker | title=Shielding Space Travelers | journal=Scientific American | volume=294 | issue=3 | pages=40–7 | date=March 2006| bibcode=2006SciAm.294c..40P | doi=10.1038/scientificamerican0306-40 | pmid=16502610 }}</ref> For passive mass shielding, the required amount could be too heavy to be affordably lifted into space without changes in economics (like hypothetical [[non-rocket spacelaunch]] or usage of extraterrestrial resources) — many hundreds of metric tons for a reasonably-sized crew compartment. For instance, a NASA design study for an ambitious large spacestation envisioned 4 metric tons per square meter of shielding to drop radiation exposure to 2.5 mSv annually (± a factor of 2 uncertainty), less than the tens of millisieverts or more in some populated [[Background Radiation#Natural background radiation|high natural background radiation areas]] on Earth, but the sheer mass for that level of mitigation was considered practical only because it involved first building a lunar [[mass driver]] to launch material.<ref name = mass_shielding/>
Several active shielding methods have been considered that might be less massive than passive shielding, but they remain speculative.<ref name="islandone.org"/><ref>[http://engineering.dartmouth.edu/~simon_g_shepherd/research/Shielding/docs/ToMaSS.pdf Simulations of Magnetic Shields for Spacecraft]. Retrieved 3 May 2011.</ref> Since the type of radiation penetrating farthest through thick material shielding, deep in interplanetary space, is GeV positively charged nuclei, a repulsive electrostatic field has been proposed, but this has problems including plasma instabilities and the power needed for an accelerator constantly keeping the charge from being neutralized by deep-space electrons.<ref>NASA SP-413 [http://settlement.arc.nasa.gov/75SummerStudy/4appendD.html Space Settlements: A Design Study. Appendix D The Plasma Core Shield] Retrieved 3 May 2011.</ref> A more common proposal is magnetic shielding generated by superconductors (or plasma currents). Among the difficulties with this proposal is that, for a compact system, magnetic fields up to 10–20 teslas could be required around a manned spacecraft, higher than the several teslas in [[MRI]] machines. Such high fields can produce headaches and migraines in MRI patients, and long-duration exposure to such fields has not been studied. Opposing-electromagnet designs might cancel the field in the crew sections of the spacecraft, but would require more mass. It is also possible to use a combination of a magnetic field with an electrostatic field, with the spacecraft having zero total charge. The hybrid design would theoretically ameliorate the problems, but would be complex and possibly infeasible.<ref name="islandone.org"/>
Part of the uncertainty is that the effect of human exposure to galactic cosmic rays is poorly known in quantitative terms. The [[NASA Space Radiation Laboratory]] is currently studying the effects of radiation in living organisms as well as protective shielding.
===Drugs=== Another line of research is the development of drugs that enhance the body's natural capacity to repair damage caused by radiation. Some of the drugs that are being considered are [[retinoids]], which are [[vitamins]] with [[antioxidant]] properties, and molecules that retard cell division, giving the body time to fix damage before harmful mutations can be duplicated.{{Citation needed|date=April 2018}}
===Timing of missions===
Due to the potential negative effects of astronaut exposure to cosmic rays, solar activity may play a role in future space travel. Because galactic cosmic ray fluxes within the Solar System are lower during periods of strong solar activity, interplanetary travel during solar maximum should minimize the average dose to astronauts.
Although the [[Forbush decrease]] effect during coronal mass ejections can temporarily lower the flux of galactic cosmic rays, the short duration of the effect (1–3 days) and the approximately 1% chance that a CME generates a dangerous solar proton event limits the utility of timing missions to coincide with CMEs.
===Orbital selection===
Radiation dosage from the Earth's radiation belts is typically mitigated by selecting orbits that avoid the belts or pass through them relatively quickly. For example, a [[low Earth orbit]], with low inclination, will generally be below the inner belt.
The orbits of the Earth-Moon system [[Lagrange Points|Lagrange points]] {{L2}} - {{L5}} take them out of the protection of the Earth's [[magnetosphere]] for approximately two-thirds of the time.{{citation needed|date=November 2015}}
The orbits of Earth-Sun system Lagrange Points {{L1}} and {{L3}} - {{L5}} are always outside the protection of the Earth's magnetosphere.

{{Infobox television episode | title = I'll Walk You Home | series = [[Holby City]] | series_no = 18 | episode = 35 | image = Arthur Digby death.png | caption = Arthur dies surrounded by his colleagues | airdate = {{Start date|2016|06|07|df=y}} | guests = *[[Jimmy Akingbola]] as [[Antoine Malick]] *[[Lauren Drummond]] as [[Chantelle Lane]] *Elizabeth Cadwallader as Alison Jones *Hayley Carmichael as Ines Maria *[[George Rainsford (actor)|George Rainsford]] as [[Ethan Hardy]] | writer = Andy Bayliss | director = Paulette Randall | photographer = Peter Butler | length = 58 minutes<ref name=episode/> | season_article = Holby City (series 18) | episode_list = List of Holby City episodes | prev = The Sky Is Falling | next = Missing You Already }} "'''I'll Walk You Home'''" is the thirty-fifth episode of the [[Holby City (series 18)|eighteenth series]] of the British [[medical drama]] television series ''[[Holby City]]''. The episode was written by Andy Bayliss and directed by Paulette Randall, and premiered on [[BBC One]] on 7 June 2016. The episode features the death of established character [[Arthur Digby]] ([[Rob Ostlere]]), a [[Modernising Medical Careers|CT2]] doctor who had worked on the show's fictitious Keller and AAU wards. Writers worked alongside a consultant oncologist for medical advice to provide an accurate depiction of terminal cancer. The episode also features the return of two former regular characters and includes an appearance of a character from ''Holby City's'' sister-show ''[[Casualty (TV series)|Casualty]]''.
The episode was structured with positive and upbeat tones transitioning into the dark scenes focusing on death. "I'll Walk You Home" received positive reviews from critics for its "gritty" theme. All reviews noted that it was an emotional episode. Sarah Deen from the ''[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]'' branded it one of the "saddest episodes ever".
==Plot== Arthur and his wife [[Modernising Medical Careers|F1]] [[Morven Shreve|Morven Digby]] (Eleanor Fanyinka) announce their decision to go travelling. They want to spend the time Arthur has left visiting historic sites. His best friend [[Specialty registrar|CT1]] doctor [[Dominic Copeland]] ([[David Ames (actor)|David Ames]]) is upset and thinks that Arthur is being selfish. Consultant general surgeon [[Ric Griffin]] ([[Hugh Quarshie]]) tries to make Dom realise that it is Arthur's choice. He decides to distract himself by attending to patient Alison Jones (Elizabeth Cadwallader). Dom realises that he has been unfair to Arthur and they have a discussion. Dom hands Arthur war medals that were stolen from their flat months earlier. Arthur realises that he wants to stay in Holby City and live out his final days with friends.
Consultant cardiothoracic surgeon [[Jac Naylor]] ([[Rosie Marcel]]) sets [[Specialty registrar|CT1]] doctor [[Zosia March]] ([[Camilla Arfwedson]]) a series of surgical tasks to prove her worth. Zosia rises to the challenge but becomes tired of Jac's demands. Jac tells Zosia she is selfish and uncaring towards Arthur. She accuses her of giving Arthur a stent operation to advance her own career. Zosia confronts Jac and accuses her of being "cold", this does not phase Jac who ignores her. Zosia ex-boyfriend, [[Specialist registrar]] [[Oliver Valentine]] ([[James Anderson (English actor)|James Anderson]]) and [[Staff nurse]] [[Cara Martinez]] ([[Niamh Walsh]]) apologise to her for sharing a kiss. Cara gives Oliver a picture of his dead wife [[Tara Lo]] ([[Jing Lusi]]) and Zosia spots him with it. [[Staff nurse]] [[Essie Harrison]] ([[Kaye Wragg]]) rallies staff to get ready to perform a song and dance surprise for Arthur. They perform a dance routine and are joined by [[Ethan Hardy]] ([[George Rainsford (actor)|George Rainsford]]). [[Antoine Malick]] ([[Jimmy Akingbola]]) makes a video call to Arthur to wish him well.
Arthur goes to visit CEO [[Henrik Hanssen]] ([[Guy Henry (actor)|Guy Henry]]) and he tells him that he has finally realised what he wants from life. Arthur's stent bursts and he collapses on the floor. Hanssen calls a crash team and tries to comfort Arthur. [[Consultant (medicine)|Consultant]] [[Sacha Levy]] ([[Bob Barrett (actor)|Bob Barrett]]) and Ric try to operate on Arthur. Sacha announces that the cancer is too advanced and nothing more can be done and Ric agrees. Hanssen goes to AAU to inform Morven who is in theatre with [[Serena Campbell]] ([[Catherine Russell (actress)|Catherine Russell]]). Arthur is taken into a side room where Morven tells him that she loves him. Arthur is unconscious and has visions of Morven, Dom, Zosia and his old friend [[Chantelle Lane]] ([[Lauren Drummond]]). Arthur responds to Morven holding his hand but then dies surrounded by his friends and colleagues. Zosia breaks down on Darwin ward and Jac rushes to console her.
==Production== The episode focuses around the final scenes of Rob Ostlere as Arthur Digby following three years in the show. The actor had informed producers of his decision to leave six months prior. They then devised an exit storyline for the character in which he is diagnosed with terminal cancer. Ostlere was told of their intention to kill the character off, the results of which play out in "I'll Walk You Home".<ref name=woti/> The events of the episode could have been different as producer Simon Harper later gave Ostlere the chance to have his character leave the show alive.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Kilkelly|first1=Daniel|title=Holby City producers reveal that Rob Ostlere could have saved his character Arthur Digby|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/soaps/holby-city/news/a796974/holby-city-rob-ostlere-arthur-digby-could-have-been-saved/|website=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=([[Hearst Magazines UK]])|accessdate=8 June 2016|date=8 June 2016}}</ref>
The episode was produced by Jane Wallbank, written by Andy Bayliss and directed by Paulette Randall.<ref name=episode>{{cite web|title=I'll Walk You Home|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b07f72gb|website=[[BBC Online]]|accessdate=8 June 2016}}</ref> Storyliners had been liaising with a consultant oncologist named Bruce Sizer who gave advice on the medical condition featured in the episode.<ref>{{cite web|title=Arthur's last walk|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p03xk5d1|website=[[BBC Online]]|accessdate=8 June 2016|date=8 June 2016}}</ref> Writers structured the episode so it began "lovely and upbeat" until the closing scenes which contained Arthur's death.<ref name=woti/>
Former regular cast members Jimmy Akingbola and Lauren Drummond returned to filming especially for the episode, reprising their roles as Antoine Malick and Chantelle Lane respectively. Akingbola filmed scenes which were featured in a [[Skype]] video call. Drummond filmed scenes with other cast members, with her footage stylised as part of a dream sequence envisioned by Arthur.<ref name=woti/> The cast were involved in filming a number of dream sequences which were given a "surreal" feeling to them.<ref name=wotint>{{cite journal|title=Arthur's final journey|journal=[[What's on TV]]|date=4–10 June 2016|issue=22|pages=15|publisher=[[IPC Media]]}}</ref>
George Rainsford guest starred as Ethan Hardy, a character from ''Holby City's'' sister-show ''[[Casualty (TV series)|Casualty]]''. His inclusion was a result of a decision made by executive producer Oliver Kent who oversees both shows. Rainsford and Ostlere had been asking Kent for the scenes for some time. The actors were friends for fourteen years and wanted their characters to share screen-time.<ref name=woti>{{cite web|title='It was a lovely, upbeat episode until Arthur's final moments!' Rob Ostlere reacts to his sudden Holby exit|url=http://www.whatsontv.co.uk/holby-city/news/it-was-a-lovely-upbeat-episode-until-arthurs-final-moments-rob-ostlere-reacts-to-his-sudden-holby-exit|website=[[What's on TV]]|publisher=([[IPC Media]])|accessdate=8 June 2016|date=7 June 2016}}</ref> After filming had wrapped for the episode Ostlere was supposed to give a farewell speech to the cast and crew but he was too upset.<ref name=departure/>
==Promotion== Producers wanted to keep exact details of the episode a secret until it was broadcast. They also wanted to Akingbola and Drummond's involvement quiet to surprise viewers.<ref name=insidesoap/> Though Ostlere did disclose that past characters would return in an interview published via ''[[What's on TV]]''.<ref name=wotint/> Advance spoilers only indicated that Arthur and Morven planned to leave ''Holby City'' to go travelling and that Zosia and Jac would feature in scenes on the show's Darwin ward.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Goodbye Arthur & Morven?|journal=[[Inside Soap]]|date=4–10 June 2016|issue=22|pages=27|publisher=[[Hearst Magazines UK]]}}</ref> The show released a promotional trailer for the episode a week in advance. It featured various characters and included parts of scenes that form Arthur's exit from the show.<ref>{{cite web|title=Trail: Next week on Holby City|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p03wvd57|website=[[BBC Online]]|accessdate=8 June 2016}}</ref> It was broadcast on 7 June 2016 on [[BBC One]] in the United Kingdom. A re-run was shown on [[BBC Two]] on 13 June 2016.<ref name=episode/><ref>{{cite web|last1=Kilkelly|first1=Daniel|title=Holby City spoiler: 'I'll Walk You Home'|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/soaps/holby-city/spoilers/a796147/holby-city-spoiler-morven-arthur-want-to-travel-the-world/|website=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=([[Hearst Magazines UK]])|accessdate=9 June 2016|date=1 June 2016}}</ref>
==Reception== The episode was watched by 4.4 million people during the BBC One airing.<ref>{{cite web|title=Weekly top 30 programmes|url=http://www.barb.co.uk/viewing-data/weekly-top-30/|website=[[Broadcasters' Audience Research Board]]|accessdate=22 June 2016}}</ref> Arthur's death was nominated for "Best Drama Storyline" at the 2016 ''Inside Soap'' Awards.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/soaps/eastenders/news/a798505/inside-soap-awards-2016-longlist/|title=Inside Soap Awards 2016 longlist revealed: Which of your soap favourites are up for prizes?|last=Sandwell|first=Ian|date=21 June 2016|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=([[Hearst Magazines UK]])|accessdate=21 June 2016}}</ref>
Laura Jayne-Tyler from ''[[Inside Soap]]'' said "Wow. That was one hell of an episode of Holby City." She added it was a struggle to recover from the "tear-jerking instalment" episode.<ref name=insidesoap>{{cite web|last1=Tyler|first1=Laura-Jayne|title=Spoilers! Holby City – what a shocker of an episode!|url=http://www.insidesoap.co.uk/spoilers-holby-city-what-a-shocker-of-an-episode/|website=[[Inside Soap]]|publisher=([[Hearst Magazines UK]])|accessdate=8 June 2016|date=7 June 2016}}</ref> Sara Wallis from the ''[[Daily Mirror]]'' noted that hospital dramas can be emotional, but branded "I'll Walk You Home" a "particularly gritty and gruelling episode".<ref name=sarwilmirror>{{cite web|last1=Wallis|first1=Sara|title=Get your tissues at the ready for cancer-stricken Arthur Digby's Holby City exit tonight|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/tv/tv-previews/your-tissues-ready-cancer-stricken-8126606|website=[[Daily Mirror]]|publisher=([[Trinity Mirror]])|accessdate=8 June 2016|date=7 June 2016}}</ref> Another ''Daily Mirror'' critic warned viewers that it was "best to keep the hankies to hand" because the episode is emotional. They added the episode was full of surprises for Arthur.<ref>{{cite web|title=Goodbye Arthur. Best TV we love|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-454272702.html|website=[[Daily Mirror]]|publisher=([[Trinity Mirror]] via [[Highbeam Research]])|accessdate=8 June 2016|date=4 June 2016}}{{subscriptionrequired}}</ref> Sarah Deen from the ''[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]'' said that his death "might be one of its saddest episodes ever". She called Arthur being readmitted to hospital "the most heartbreaking scenes". The scene involving Zosia and Jac breaking down in each other's arms "left viewers completely overcome with emotion". Deen concluded that "Holby really does pull at the heart strings when it’s ready."<ref name=finalscenes>{{cite web|last1=Deen|first1=Sarah|title=‘Bawling like a baby!’ Viewers get emotional over Holby City as cancer-stricken Arthur Digby dies|url=http://metro.co.uk/2016/06/07/balling-like-a-baby-viewers-get-emotional-over-holby-city-as-cancer-stricken-arthur-digby-dies-5930204/|website=[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]|publisher=([[DMG Media]])|accessdate=8 June 2016|date=7 June 2016}}</ref>
Kayleigh Dray from ''[[Closer (magazine)|Closer]]'' said the fact the episode featured the death of a "popular character" and made "tearjerking scenes". The critic noted that her colleagues were upset, adding "Oh Arthur, why did you have to ruin our makeup like that? We cried SO many tears for you."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Dray|first1=Kayleigh|title=Holby City spoilers: Dr Arthur Digby’s funeral rocked by major disaster|url=http://lifestyle.one/closer/entertainment/soaps/holby-city-arthur-digby-cancer-dead-funeral-disaster/|website=[[Closer (magazine)|Closer]]|publisher=([[Bauer Media Group]])|accessdate=8 June 2016|date=8 June 2016}}</ref> Frances Taylor from [[Bt.com]] said "fans of the BBC hospital drama were left weeping after the episode aired." She noted that the episode caused many viewers to discuss the show on social media website [[Twitter]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Taylor|first1=Frances|title=Holby City fans left distraught after Arthur Digby dies|url=http://tv.bt.com/tv/tv-soap/holby-city-fans-left-distraught-after-arthur-digby-dies-11364066699838|website=[[Bt.com]]|publisher=([[BT Group]])|accessdate=8 June 2016|date=8 June 2016}}</ref> Daniel Kilkelly from [[Digital Spy]] said it was a "heartbreaking episode". He chose the scenes in which Arthur was rushed to surgery as the most "tearjerking scenes".<ref name=departure>{{cite web|last1=Kilkelly|first1=Daniel|title=Holby City's Rob Ostlere reacts to Arthur Digby's emotional exit: 'It sparks a lot of change'|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/soaps/holby-city/interviews/a796914/holby-citys-rob-ostlere-arthur-digby-exit/|website=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=([[Hearst Magazines UK]])|accessdate=8 June 2016}}</ref> The episode was included in a "TV Highlights" feature in ''[[TVTimes]]'' magazine and was given a three out of a possible four star rating.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Tuesday highlights|journal=[[TVTimes]]|publisher=[[IPC Media]]|date=4–10 June 2016|volume=231|issue=23|pages=58}}</ref> The episode was included in ''[[Soaplife]]'' magazine's "must see TV" feature.<ref>{{cite journal|date=4–17 June 2016|title=Must see TV|journal=[[Soaplife]]|publisher=[[IPC Media]]|issue=382|page=62}}</ref> The episode was also chosen for the "Pick of the day" features in the ''[[Coventry Telegraph]]'' and ''[[South Wales Echo]]''.<ref>{{cite web|first=Sara|last=Wallis|title=Doctor's in a Spin; Chats with Henrik Hanssen and Ric pick of the day Holby City BBC1, 8pm|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-454308025.html|website=[[Coventry Telegraph]]|publisher=([[Trinity Mirror]] via [[Highbeam Research]])|accessdate=9 June 2016|date=7 June 2016}}{{subscriptionrequired}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|first=Sara|last=Wallis|title=Doctor's in a Spin; pick of the day Holby City, 8pm|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-454405039.html|website=[[South Wales Echo]]|publisher=([[Trinity Mirror]] via [[Highbeam Research]])|accessdate=9 June 2016|date=7 June 2016}}{{subscriptionrequired}}</ref> Due to the tough subject matter, a writer from the ''[[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]]'' branded it "Holby Gritty".<ref>{{cite web|title=TV record|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-454380688.html|website=[[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]]|publisher=([[Trinity Mirror]] via [[Highbeam Research]])|accessdate=9 June 2016|date=7 June 2016}}{{subscriptionrequired}}</ref> Anthony D. Langford writing for ''[[TVSource Magazine]]'' said "Arthur’s death was very sad as I thought it would be. He was one of my faves on this show. I’ll miss him. I did mist up a few times during this episode, mostly during the song his co-workers sang to him. And Zosia’s reaction got me too."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tvsourcemagazine.com/2016/06/gays-lives-padres-new-lover/2/|title=Gays of Our Lives: The Padre’s New Lover?|last=D. Langford|first=Anthony|date=13 June 2016|work=[[TVSource Magazine]]|publisher=(SoSource Media)|accessdate=2 July 2016}}</ref>

revision.comment: Journal cites:, added 1 PMID, added 2 PMCs using [[Project:AWB|AWB]] (12150)
revision.text:
'''I-''Cre''I''' is a [[homing endonuclease]] whose [[gene]] was first discovered in the [[chloroplast]] genome of ''[[Chlamydomonas reinhardtii]]'', a species of unicellular [[green algae]].<ref name="rochaix">{{cite journal | last1 = Rochaix | first1 = JD | last2 = Malnoe | first2 = P | year = 1978 | title = Anatomy of the chloroplast ribosomal DNA of ''Chlamydomonas reinhardtii'' | url = | journal = Cell | volume = 15 | issue = | pages = 661–670 | doi=10.1016/0092-8674(78)90034-x}}</ref> It is named for the facts that: it resides in an '''I'''ntron; it was isolated from '''''C'''lamydomonas '''re'''inhardtii''; it was the first ('''I''') such gene isolated from ''C. reinhardtii''. Its gene resides in a group I [[intron]] in the 23S [[ribosomal RNA]] gene of the ''C. reinhardtii'' chloroplast, and I-''Cre''I is only expressed when its [[mRNA]] is spliced from the [[transcription (genetics)|primary transcript]] of the 23S gene. I-''Cre''I [[enzyme]], which functions as a [[homodimer]], recognizes a 22-nucleotide sequence of duplex DNA and cleaves one phosphodiester bond on each strand at specific positions. I-''Cre''I is a member of the [[Homing endonuclease#Structural families|LAGLIDADG family]] of homing endonucleases, all of which have a conserved LAGLIDADG amino acid motif that contributes to their associative domains and active sites. When the I-''Cre''I-containing intron encounters a 23S gene lacking the intron, I-''Cre''I enzyme "homes" in on the "intron-minus" allele of 23S and effects its parent intron's insertion into the intron-minus allele. Introns with this behavior are called [[mobile introns]]. Because I-''Cre''I provides for its own propagation while conferring no benefit on its host, it is an example of [[selfish DNA]].
==Discovery== I-''Cre''I was first observed as an [[intron|intervening sequence]] in the 23S [[rRNA]] gene of the ''C. reinhardtii'' chloroplast genome.<ref name="rochaix" /> The 23S gene is an [[RNA gene]], meaning that its transcript is not translated into protein. As RNA, it forms part of the large subunit of the [[ribosome]]. An open reading frame coding for a 163-amino acid protein was found in this 23S intron, suggesting that a protein might facilitate the homing behavior of the mobile intron. Furthermore, the predicted protein had a LAGLIDADG motif, a conserved amino acid sequence that is present in other proteins coded for in group I mobile introns. A 1991 study established that the ORF codes for a DNA endonuclease, I-''Cre''I, which selectively cuts a site corresponding to where the intron is spliced out of the 23S primary transcript.<ref name="durrenberger">{{cite journal | last1 = Dürrenberger | first1 = F | last2 = Rochaix | first2 = JD | year = 1991 | title = Chloroplast ribosomal intron of ''Chlamydomonas reinhardtii'': ''in vitro'' self-splicing, DNA endonuclease activity and ''in vivo'' mobility | journal = EMBO J | volume = 10 | issue = | pages = 3495–3501 | pmid = 1915304 | pmc=453078}}</ref> The study also showed that the intron was able to invade 23S alleles that did not already have it.<ref name="durrenberger" />
==Mechanism of propagation== I-''Cre''I has evolved to cut a 22-nucleotide sequence of DNA that occurs in [[allele]]s of the 23S ribosomal RNA gene that lack the I-''Cre''I-containing intron. When such an "intron-minus" allele is cut, pathways of [[DNA repair#Double-strand breaks|double-strand break repair]] are activated in the cell. The cell uses as a template for repair the 23S allele that yielded the responsible I-''Cre''I enzyme, thus replicating the I-''Cre''I-containing intron.<ref name="durrenberger2">{{cite journal | last1 = Dürrenberger | first1 = F | last2 = Thompson | first2 = AJ | last3 = Herrin | first3 = DL | last4 = Rochaix | first4 = JD | year = 1996 | title = Double strand break-induced recombination in ''Chlamydomonas reinhardtii'' chloroplasts | url = | journal = Nucleic Acids Research | volume = 24 | issue = | pages = 3323–3331 | doi=10.1093/nar/24.17.3323}}</ref> The resulting "intron-plus" allele no longer contains an intact homing site for the I-''Cre''I enzyme, and is therefore not cleaved. Since this intron provides for its own replication without conferring any benefit on its host, I-''Cre''I is a form of [[selfish DNA]].
==Structural studies and possible applications== [[Image:cre crystal structure.png|right|thumbnail|400px|X-ray crystal structure of I-''Cre''I bound to its native homing site.<ref name="jurica">{{cite journal | last1 = Jurica | first1 = MS | last2 = Monnat | first2 = RJ | last3 = Stoddard | first3 = BL | year = 1998 | title = DNA Recognition and Cleavage by the LAGLIDADG Homing Endonuclease I-''Cre''I. | url = | journal = Molecular Cell | volume = 2 | issue = | pages = 469–476 | doi=10.1016/s1097-2765(00)80146-x | pmid=9809068}}</ref>]] Because I-''Cre''I has evolved to cut such a long sequence of DNA, unlike [[restriction endonucleases]] that typically cut four- or six-nucleotide sequences, it is capable of cutting a single site within a very large [[genome]]. A four- or six-nucleotide sequence is expected to occur many, many times in a genome of millions or billions of nucleotides simply by chance, whereas a 22-nucleotide sequence might occur only once (10<sup>9</sup>/4<sup>6</sup> vs. 10<sup>9</sup>/4<sup>22</sup>). This specificity of I-''Cre''I cleavage makes I-''Cre''I a promising tool for [[gene therapy|gene targeting]]. If a person were to have a disease due to a defective [[allele]] of some [[gene]], it would be helpful to be able to replace that allele with a functional one. If one could cause I-''Cre''I to cut the DNA only in the defective allele while simultaneously providing a normal allele for the cell to use as a repair template, the patient's own [[homologous recombination]] machinery could insert the desired allele in place of the dysfunctional one. The specificity of I-''Cre''I also allows for the reduction of deleterious effects due to [[DNA repair#DNA repair mechanisms|double-strand breaks]] outside of the gene of interest.
In order to use I-''Cre''I as a tool in this fashion, it is necessary to make it recognize and cleave sequences of DNA different from its native homing site. An ''[[Escherichia coli]]'' genetic system for studying the relationship between I-''Cre''I structure and its homing site specificity was created in 1997.<ref name="seligman">{{cite journal | last1 = Seligman | first1 = LM | last2 = Stephens | first2 = KM | last3 = Savage | first3 = JH | last4 = Monnat | first4 = RJ | year = 1997 | title = Genetic Analysis of the ''Chlamydomonas reinhardtii'' I-''Cre''I Mobile intron Homing System in ''Escherichia coli'' | url = | journal = Genetics | volume = 147 | issue = | pages = 1653–1664 }}</ref> In 1997, the structure of the I-CreI protein was determined,<ref name="pmid9187655">{{cite journal | author = Heath, P.| title = The structure of I-Crel, a group I intron-encoded homing endonuclease | journal = Nature Structural Biology | volume = 4 | issue = 6 |date=June 1997 | pages = 468–476 | pmid = 9187655 | doi=10.1038/nsb0697-468 |display-authors=etal}}</ref> and in 1998, its crystal structure bound to its native DNA homing site was solved, greatly aiding research in altering the homing site recognition of the protein.<ref name="jurica" /> Mutant forms of the protein have since been created that exhibit altered homing site specificity.<ref name="seligman2">{{cite journal | last1 = Seligman | first1 = LM | last2 = Chisholm | first2 = KM | last3 = Chevalier | first3 = BS | last4 = Chadsey | first4 = MS | last5 = Edwards | first5 = ST | last6 = Savage | first6 = JH | last7 = Veillet | first7 = AL | year = 2002 | title = Mutations altering the cleavage specificity of a homing endonuclease | url = | journal = Nucleic Acids Research | volume = 30 | issue = | pages = 3870–3879 | doi=10.1093/nar/gkf495 | pmid=12202772 | pmc=137417}}</ref><ref name="seligman3">{{cite journal | last1 = Sussman | first1 = D | last2 = Chadsey | first2 = M | last3 = Fauce | first3 = S | last4 = Engel | first4 = A | last5 = Bruett | first5 = A | last6 = Monnat | first6 = R | last7 = Stoddard | first7 = BL | last8 = Seligman | first8 = LM | year = 2004 | title = Isolation and Characterization of New Homing Endonuclease Specificities at Individual Target Site Positions | url = | journal = Journal of Molecular Biology | volume = 342 | issue = | pages = 31–41 | doi=10.1016/j.jmb.2004.07.031 | pmid=15313605}}</ref><ref name="seligman4">{{cite journal | last1 = Rosen | first1 = LE | last2 = Morrison | first2 = HA | last3 = Masri | first3 = S | last4 = Brown | first4 = MJ | last5 = Springstubb | first5 = B | last6 = Sussman | first6 = D | last7 = Stoddard | first7 = BL | last8 = Seligman | first8 = LM | year = 2006 | title = Homing endonuclease I-''Cre''I derivatives with novel DNA target specificities | url = | journal = Nucleic Acids Research | volume = 34 | issue = | pages = 4791–4800 | doi=10.1093/nar/gkl645 | pmid=16971456 | pmc=1635285}}</ref> A genetic system in ''[[Saccharomyces cerevisiae]]'' has also been created, yielding additional I-''Cre''I mutants with modified homing site specificities.<ref name="arnould">{{cite journal | last1 = Arnould | first1 = S | last2 = Chames | first2 = P | last3 = Perez | first3 = C | last4 = Lacroix | first4 = E | last5 = Duclert | first5 = A | last6 = Epinat | first6 = JC | last7 = Stricher | first7 = F | last8 = Petit | first8 = AS | last9 = Patin | first9 = A | last10 = Guillier | first10 = S | last11 = Rolland | first11 = S | last12 = Prieto | first12 = J | last13 = Blanco | first13 = FJ | last14 = Bravo | first14 = J | last15 = Montoya | first15 = G | last16 = Serrano | first16 = L | last17 = Duchateau | first17 = P | last18 = Pâques | first18 = F | year = 2006 | title = Engineering of Large Numbers of Highly Specific Homing Endonucleases that Induce Recombination on Novel DNA Targets | url = | journal = Journal of Molecular Biology | volume = 355 | issue = | pages = 443–458 | doi=10.1016/j.jmb.2005.10.065 | pmid=16310802}}</ref><ref name="smith">{{cite journal | last1 = Smith | first1 = J | last2 = Grizot | first2 = S | last3 = Arnould | first3 = S | last4 = Duclert | first4 = A | last5 = Epinat | first5 = JC | last6 = Chames | first6 = P | last7 = Prieto | first7 = J | last8 = Redondo | first8 = P | last9 = Blanco | first9 = FJ | last10 = Bravo | first10 = J | last11 = Montoya | first11 = G | last12 = Pâques | first12 = F | last13 = Duchateau | first13 = P | year = 2006 | title = A combinatorial approach to create artificial homing endonucleases cleaving chosen sequences | url = | journal = Nucleic Acids Research | volume = 34| pmc=1702487 | pmid=17130168 | doi=10.1093/nar/gkl720 | pages=e149}}</ref>
I-''Cre''I has already been used successfully to induce homologous recombination in ''[[Drosophila melanogaster]]'', an extremely popular [[eukaryote|eukaryotic]] [[model organism]].<ref name="maggert">{{cite journal | last1 = Maggert | first1 = KA | last2 = Golic | first2 = KG | year = 2005 | title = Highly Efficient Sex Chromosome Interchanges Produced By I-''Cre''I Expression in ''Drosophila'' | journal = Genetics | volume = 171 | issue = | pages = 1103–1114 | doi=10.1534/genetics.104.040071 | pmid=16020774 | pmc=1456814}}</ref> It seems very likely that advances in molecular biological techniques and generation of a library of I-''Cre''I-derived novel endonucleases will eventually allow for the targeting of many genes of etiological significance.
