revision.text:
'''Mycoviruses''' (ancient Greek μύκης mykes: fungus and Latin [[virus]]) are [[viruses]] that infect [[fungi]]. Mycoviruses are also known as mycophage.The majority of mycoviruses have double-stranded RNA (dsRNA) genomes and isometric particles, but approximately 30% have positive sense, single-stranded RNA (+ssRNA) genomes.<ref name="Pearson">{{cite journal | vauthors = Pearson MN, Beever RE, Boine B, Arthur K | title = Mycoviruses of filamentous fungi and their relevance to plant pathology | journal = Molecular Plant Pathology | volume = 10 | issue = 1 | pages = 115–28 | date = January 2009 | pmid = 19161358 | doi = 10.1111/j.1364-3703.2008.00503.x }}</ref><ref name="Boz">{{cite journal | vauthors = Bozarth RF | title = Mycoviruses: a new dimension in microbiology | journal = Environmental Health Perspectives | volume = 2 | issue = 1 | pages = 23–39 | date = October 1972 | pmid = 4628853 | pmc = 1474899 | doi = 10.1289/ehp.720223 }}</ref> To be a true '''mycovirus''', they must demonstrate an ability to be transmitted - in other words be able to infect other healthy fungi. Many double stranded RNA elements that have been described in fungi do not fit this description, and in these cases they are referred to as virus like particles or [[Virus-like particle|VLPs]]. Preliminary results indicate that most mycoviruses codiverge with their hosts, i.e. their [[phylogeny]] is largely congruent with the one of their hosts.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Göker M, Scheuner C, Klenk HP, Stielow JB, Menzel W | title = Codivergence of mycoviruses with their hosts | journal = PLOS One | volume = 6 | issue = 7 | pages = e22252 | year = 2011 | pmid = 21829452 | pmc = 3146478 | doi = 10.1371/journal.pone.0022252 }}</ref> However, many virus families containing mycoviruses have only sparsely been sampled.
==Mycovirology== Mycovirology<ref name= "Ghabrial">{{cite journal | vauthors = Ghabrial SA, Suzuki N | title = Viruses of plant pathogenic fungi | journal = Annual Review of Phytopathology | volume = 47 | issue = | pages = 353–84 | year = 2009 | pmid = 19400634 | doi = 10.1146/annurev-phyto-080508-081932 }}</ref> is the study of viruses infecting fungi, also called mycoviruses. It is a special subdivision of the general field of [[virology]] and describes taxonomy, host range, origin and evolution, transmission and movement of mycoviruses and their impact on host phenotype.
==History== The first record of an economic impact of mycoviruses on fungi was recorded in cultivated mushrooms (''[[Agaricus bisporus]]'') in the late 1940s and was called the La France disease.<ref name="Hollings" >{{cite journal | vauthors = Hollings M | year=1962 |title=Viruses Associated with A Die-Back Disease of Cultivated Mushroom |journal=Nature |volume=196 |issue=4858 |pages=962–965 |doi=10.1038/196962a0 }}</ref> Hollings found more than three different types of viruses in the abnormal [[sporophore]]s. This report marks the beginning of [[mycovirology]].<ref name="Ghabrial" />
The La France Disease is also known as X disease, watery stripe, dieback and brown disease. [[Symptoms]] include: * Reduced [[Crop yield|yield]] * Slow and aberrant [[mycelial]] growth * Waterlogging of tissue * [[malformation]] * Premature maturation * Increased post-harvest deterioration (reduced shelf life)<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Romaine CP, Schlagnhaufer B | title = PCR analysis of the viral complex associated with La France disease of Agaricus bisporus | journal = Applied and Environmental Microbiology | volume = 61 | issue = 6 | pages = 2322–5 | date = June 1995 | pmid = 7793952 | pmc = 167503 | doi = }}</ref>
Mushrooms have shown no resistance to the virus, and so control has had to be via [[hygienic]] practises to stop the spread of the virus.
However, the best known mycovirus is ''[[Cryphonectria parasitica]]'' hypovirus 1 (CHV1). CHV1 is exceptional amongst mycoviral research due its success as biocontrol agent against chestnut blight in Europe, but also because it is a model organism for studying hypovirulence in fungi. However, this system is only being used in Europe routinely, because of the relative small number of vegetative compatibility groups (VCGs) on this continent. In contrast, in North America the distribution of the hypovirulent phenotype is often prevented because fungal hyphae cannot fuse and exchange their cytoplasmic content due to an incompatibility reaction. In the United States of America at least 35 VCGs were found.<ref name=Anagnostakis >{{cite journal | vauthors = Anagnostakis SL, Chen B, Geletka LM, Nuss DL | title = Hypovirus Transmission to Ascospore Progeny by Field-Released Transgenic Hypovirulent Strains of Cryphonectria parasitica | journal = Phytopathology | volume = 88 | issue = 7 | pages = 598–604 | date = July 1998 | pmid = 18944931 | doi = 10.1094/PHYTO.1998.88.7.598 }}</ref> A similar situation seems to be present in China and Japan where 71 VCGs were identified so far.<ref name=Liu&Milgroom >{{cite journal | vauthors = Liu YC, Milgroom MG | title = High diversity of vegetative compatibility types in Cryphonectria parasitica in Japan and China | journal = Mycologia | volume = 99 | issue = 2 | pages = 279–84 | year = 2007 | pmid = 17682780 | doi = 10.3852/mycologia.99.2.279 | url = http://www.mycologia.org/content/99/2/279.full.pdf }}</ref>
==Taxonomy== The majority of mycoviruses have double-stranded RNA (dsRNA) genomes and isometric particles, but approximately 30% have positive sense, single-stranded RNA (+ssRNA) genomes.<ref name="Pearson" /><ref name="Boz" /> So far there is only one true example of a single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) mycovirus. A geminivirus-related virus was found in ''[[Sclerotinia sclerotiorum]]'' conferring hypovirulence to its host.<ref name= "Yu">{{cite journal | vauthors = Yu X, Li B, Fu Y, Jiang D, Ghabrial SA, Li G, Peng Y, Xie J, Cheng J, Huang J, Yi X | title = A geminivirus-related DNA mycovirus that confers hypovirulence to a plant pathogenic fungus | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America | volume = 107 | issue = 18 | pages = 8387–92 | date = May 2010 | pmid = 20404139 | pmc = 2889581 | doi = 10.1073/pnas.0913535107 }}</ref> The updated 9th ICTV report on virus taxonomy<ref>[http://www.ictvonline.org], King, A. M. Q., Lefkowitz E. M., Adams, J., Carstens, E. B. (2011). Virus Taxonomy: Ninth Report of the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV). San Diego, CA: Elsevier Academic.</ref> lists over 90 mycovirus species covering 10 viral families, of which 20% were unassigned to a genus or sometimes not even to a family. Isometric forms predominate mycoviral morphologies in comparison to rigid rods, flexuous rods, clubshaped particles, enveloped bacilliform particles, and Herpesvirus-like viruses.<ref name="Varga">{{cite journal | vauthors = Varga J, Tóth B, Vágvölgyi C | title = Recent advances in mycovirus research | journal = Acta Microbiologica et Immunologica Hungarica | volume = 50 | issue = 1 | pages = 77–94 | year = 2003 | pmid = 12793203 | doi = 10.1556/AMicr.50.2003.1.8 }}</ref> The lack of genomic data often hampers a conclusive assignment to already established groups of viruses or makes it impossible to erect new families and genera. The latter is true for many unencapsidated dsRNA viruses, which are assumed to be viral, but missing sequence data prevented their classification so far.<ref name="Pearson" /> So far, viruses of the families ''[[Partitiviridae]]'', ''[[Totiviridae]]'', and ''[[Narnaviridae]]'' are dominating the ‘mycovirus sphere’.
[[File:Listing of all formally named and recognised mycoviruses.png|thumb|Listing of all formally named and recognised mycoviruses summarised from “Virus Taxonomy: The Ninth Report of the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses” (King et al., 2011).]]
==Host range and incidence== Mycoviruses are common in fungi (Herrero et al., 2009) and are found in all four phyla of the true fungi: ''Chytridiomycota'', ''Zygomycota'', ''[[Ascomycota]]'' and ''[[Basidiomycota]]''. Fungi are frequently infected with two or more unrelated viruses and also with defective dsRNA and/or satellite dsRNA.<ref name="Ghabrial2">Ghabrial, S. A., Suzuki, N. (2008). Fungal Viruses. In B. W. J. Mahy and M. H. V. Van Regenmortel (ed.), Encyclopedia of Virology, 3rd ed., vol. 2. Elsevier, Oxford, United Kingdom. p. 284-291.</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Howitt RL, Beever RE, Pearson MN, Forster RL | title = Genome characterization of a flexuous rod-shaped mycovirus, Botrytis virus X, reveals high amino acid identity to genes from plant 'potex-like' viruses | journal = Archives of Virology | volume = 151 | issue = 3 | pages = 563–79 | date = March 2006 | pmid = 16172841 | doi = 10.1007/s00705-005-0621-y }}</ref> There are also viruses that simply use fungi as vectors and are distinct from mycoviruses, because they cannot reproduce in the fungal cytoplasm.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Adams|first1=M. J.|year=1991|title=Transmission of plant viruses by fungi|journal=Annals of Applied Biology|volume=118|issue=2|pages=479–492|doi=10.1111/j.1744-7348.1991.tb05649.x|url=}}</ref> It is generally assumed that the natural host range of mycoviruses is confined to closely related vegetability compatibility groups that allow for cytoplasmic fusion,<ref>Buck, K. W. (1986). Fungal Virology- An overview', in K. Buck (ed.), Fungal Virology (Boca Raton: CRC Press): 1-84.</ref> but some mycoviruses can replicate in taxonomically different fungal hosts.<ref name="Ghabrial" /> Good examples are mitoviruses found in the two fungal species ''Sclerotinia homoeocarpa'' and ''Ophiostoma novo-ulmi''.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Deng F, Xu R, Boland GJ | title = Hypovirulence-Associated Double-Stranded RNA from Sclerotinia homoeocarpa Is Conspecific with Ophiostoma novo-ulmi Mitovirus 3a-Ld | journal = Phytopathology | volume = 93 | issue = 11 | pages = 1407–14 | date = November 2003 | pmid = 18944069 | doi = 10.1094/PHYTO.2003.93.11.1407 }}</ref> Nuss et al. (2005) described that it is possible to extend the natural host range of ''[[Cryphonectria parasitica]]'' hypovirus 1 (CHV1) to several fungal species that are closely related to ''[[Cryphonectria parasitica]]'' using in vitro virus transfection techniques.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Chen B, Choi GH, Nuss DL | title = Attenuation of fungal virulence by synthetic infectious hypovirus transcripts | journal = Science | volume = 264 | issue = 5166 | pages = 1762–4 | date = June 1994 | pmid = 8209256 | doi = 10.1126/science.8209256 }}</ref> CHV1 can also propagate in the genera ''Endothia'' and ''Valsa'',<ref name="Ghabrial2" /> which belong to the two distinct families ''Cryphonectriaceae'' and ''Diaporthaceae'', respectively. Furthermore, some human pathogenic fungi are also found to be naturally infected with mycoviruses including AfuPmV-1 of ''[[Aspergillus fumigatus]]'' <ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Kotta-Loizou I, Coutts RH | title = Aspergilli: A Comprehensive Review | language = English | journal = Frontiers in Microbiology | volume = 8 | pages = 1699 | date = 2017 | pmid = 28932216 | pmc = 5592211 | doi = 10.3389/fmicb.2017.01699 }}</ref> and TmPV1 of ''[[Penicillium marneffei|Talaromyces marneffei]]'' <ref name=":0">{{cite journal | vauthors = Lau SK, Lo GC, Chow FW, Fan RY, Cai JJ, Yuen KY, Woo PC | title = Novel Partitivirus Enhances Virulence of and Causes Aberrant Gene Expression in Talaromyces marneffei | journal = mBio | volume = 9 | issue = 3 | pages = e00947–18 | date = June 2018 | pmid = 29895639 | pmc = 6016240 | doi = 10.1128/mBio.00947-18 | url = https://mbio.asm.org/content/9/3/e00947-18 }}</ref>''(formerly [[Penicillium marneffei]]).''
==Origin and evolution== DsRNA as well as ssRNA are assumed to be very ancient and presumably originated from the ‘RNA world’ as both types of RNA viruses infect bacteria as well as eukaryotes.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Forterre P | title = The origin of viruses and their possible roles in major evolutionary transitions | journal = Virus Research | volume = 117 | issue = 1 | pages = 5–16 | date = April 2006 | pmid = 16476498 | doi = 10.1016/j.virusres.2006.01.010 }}</ref> Although the origin of viruses is still not well understood,<ref name="Koonin">{{cite journal | vauthors = Koonin EV, Wolf YI | title = Genomics of bacteria and archaea: the emerging dynamic view of the prokaryotic world | journal = Nucleic Acids Research | volume = 36 | issue = 21 | pages = 6688–719 | date = December 2008 | pmid = 18948295 | pmc = 2588523 | doi = 10.1093/nar/gkn668 }}</ref> recently presented data which suggest that viruses invaded the emerging ‘supergroups’ of eukaryotes from an ancestral pool in a very early stage of life on earth. According to Koonin,<ref name="Koonin" /> RNA viruses colonized eukaryotes first and subsequently co-evolved with their hosts. This concept fits well with the proposed ‘ancient co-evolution hypothesis’, which also assumes a long co-evolution of viruses and fungi.<ref name="Pearson" /><ref name="Varga" /> ‘The ancient coevolution hypothesis’ could contribute some explanation why mycoviruses are so diverse.<ref name="Varga" /><ref name="Dawe">{{cite journal | vauthors = Dawe AL, Nuss DL | title = Hypoviruses and chestnut blight: exploiting viruses to understand and modulate fungal pathogenesis | journal = Annual Review of Genetics | volume = 35 | issue = | pages = 1–29 | year = 2001 | pmid = 11700275 | doi = 10.1146/annurev.genet.35.102401.085929 }}</ref> It has also been suggested that it is very likely that plant viruses containing a movement protein have evolved from mycoviruses by introducing of an extracellular phase into their life cycle, rather than eliminating it. Furthermore, the recent discovery of an ssDNA mycovirus tempted some researchers<ref name="Yu" /> to suggest that RNA and DNA viruses might have common evolutionary mechanisms. However, there are many cases where mycoviruses are grouped together with plant viruses. For example, CHV1 showed phylogenetic relatedness to the ssRNA genus Potyvirus<ref>{{cite book | vauthors = Fauquet CM, Mayo MA, Maniloff J | date = 2005 | title = Virus Taxonomy: Classification and Nomenclature of Viruses: The Eighth Report of the International Committee on the Taxonomy of Viruses. | location = San Diego, CA | publisher = Elsevier Academic }}</ref> and some ssRNA viruses, which were assumed to confer hypovirulence or debilitation, were often found to be more closely related to plant viruses than to other mycoviruses.<ref name="Pearson" /> Therefore, another theory arose that these viruses moved from a plant host to plant pathogenic fungal host or vice versa. This ‘plant virus hypothesis’ may not explain how mycoviruses developed originally, but it could help to understand how they evolved further.
==Transmission== A significant difference between the genomes of mycoviruses to other viruses is the absence of genes for ‘cell-to-cell movement’ proteins. It is therefore assumed that mycoviruses only move intercellularly during cell division (e.g. sporogenesis) or via hyphal fusion.<ref name="Ghabrial2" /><ref>{{cite book | vauthors = Ghabrial SA | date = 1994 | chapter = New Developments in Fungal Virology | veditors = Murphy FA, Maramorosch K, Aaron JS | title = Advances in Virus Research | volume = 43 | publisher = Academic Press | pages = 303–388 }}</ref> Mycoviruses might simply not need an external route of infection as they have many means of transmission and spread due to their fungal host’s life style:
* Plasmogamy and cytoplasmic exchange over extended periods of time * Production of vast amounts of asexual spores * Overwintering via sclerotia<ref name="Liu_2009">{{cite journal | vauthors = Liu H, Fu Y, Jiang D, Li G, Xie J, Peng Y, Yi X, Ghabrial SA | title = A novel mycovirus that is related to the human pathogen hepatitis E virus and rubi-like viruses | journal = Journal of Virology | volume = 83 | issue = 4 | pages = 1981–91 | date = February 2009 | pmid = 19073734 | pmc = 2643757 | doi = 10.1128/JVI.01897-08 }}</ref> * More or less effective transmission into sexual spores
However, there are potential barriers to mycovirus spread due to vegetative incompatibility and variable transmission to sexual spores. Transmission to sexually produced spores can range from 0% to 100% depending on the virus-host combination.<ref name="Ghabrial2" /> Transmission between species of the same genus sharing the same habitat has also been reported including ''Cryphonectria'' (''C. parasitica'' and ''C.'' sp), ''Sclerotinia'' (''[[Sclerotinia sclerotiorum]]'' and ''S. minor''), and ''Ophistoma'' (''O. ulmi'' and ''O. novo-ulmi'').<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Liu YC, Linder-Basso D, Hillman BI, Kaneko S, Milgroom MG | title = Evidence for interspecies transmission of viruses in natural populations of filamentous fungi in the genus Cryphonectria | journal = Molecular Ecology | volume = 12 | issue = 6 | pages = 1619–28 | date = June 2003 | pmid = 12755889 | doi = 10.1046/j.1365-294x.2003.01847.x }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Melzer MS, Deng F, Boland GJ | title = Asymptomatic infection, and distribution of ''Ophiostoma mitovirus'' 3a (OMV3a), in populations of ''Sclerotinia homoeocarpa'' | journal = Canadian Journal of Plant Pathology | date = December 2005 | volume = 27 | issue = 4 | pages = 610–5 | title-link = Sclerotinia homoeocarpa }}</ref> Intraspecies transmission has also been reported<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Van Diepeningen AD, Debets AJ, Slakhorst SM, Fekete C, Hornok L, Hoekstra RF | date = 2000 | title = Interspecies virus transfer via protoplast fusions between ''Fusarium poae'' and black ''Aspergillus'' strains. | journal = Fungal Genetics Newsletter | volume = 47 | pages = 99–100 }}</ref> between ''Fusarium poae'' and black ''[[Aspergillus]]'' isolates. However, it is not known how fungi overcome the genetic barrier; whether there is some form of recognition process during physical contact or some other means of exchange, such as vectors. Research<ref name="Diep">{{cite journal | vauthors = van Diepeningen AD, Debets AJ, Hoekstra RF | title = Dynamics of dsRNA mycoviruses in black Aspergillus populations | journal = Fungal Genetics and Biology : FG & B | volume = 43 | issue = 6 | pages = 446–52 | date = June 2006 | pmid = 16546419 | doi = 10.1016/j.fgb.2006.01.014 }}</ref> using ''[[Aspergillus]]'' species indicated that transmission efficiencies might depend on the hosts viral infection status (infected with no, different, or same virus), and that mycoviruses might play a role in the regulation of secondary mycoviral infection. Whether this is also true for other fungi is not yet known. In contrast to acquiring mycoviruses spontaneously, the loss of mycoviruses seems very infrequent<ref name="Diep" /> and suggests that either viruses actively moved into spores and new hyphal tips, or the fungus might facilitate the mycoviral transport in some other way.
==Movement of mycoviruses within fungi== Although it is not known yet whether viral transport is an active or passive process, it is generally assumed that fungal viruses move forward by plasma streaming.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Sasaki A, Kanematsu S, Onoue M, Oyama Y, Yoshida K | title = Infection of Rosellinia necatrix with purified viral particles of a member of Partitiviridae (RnPV1-W8) | journal = Archives of Virology | volume = 151 | issue = 4 | pages = 697–707 | date = April 2006 | pmid = 16307176 | doi = 10.1007/s00705-005-0662-2 }}</ref> Theoretically they could drift with the cytoplasm as it extends into new hyphae, or attach to the web of microtubuli, which would drag them through the internal cytoplasmic space. That might explain how they pass through septa and bypass woronin bodies. However, some researchers have found them located next to septum walls,<ref name="Boz" /><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Vilches S, Castillo A | title = A double-stranded RNA mycovirus in Botrytis cinerea | journal = FEMS Microbiology Letters | volume = 155 | issue = 1 | pages = 125–30 | date = October 1997 | pmid = 9345772 | doi = 10.1016/S0378-1097(97)00377-7 }}</ref> which could imply that they ‘got stuck’ and were not able to move actively forward themselves. Others have suggested that the transmission of viral mitochondrial dsRNA may play an important role in the movement of mitoviruses found in ''[[Botrytis cinerea]]''.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Wu M, Zhang L, Li G, Jiang D, Ghabrial SA | title = Genome characterization of a debilitation-associated mitovirus infecting the phytopathogenic fungus Botrytis cinerea | journal = Virology | volume = 406 | issue = 1 | pages = 117–26 | date = October 2010 | pmid = 20674953 | doi = 10.1016/j.virol.2010.07.010 }}</ref>
==Impact on host phenotype== Phenotypic effects of mycoviral infections can vary from advantageous to deleterious, but most of them are asymptomatic or cryptic. The connection between phenotype and mycovirus presence is not always straight forward. Several reasons may account for this. First, the lack of appropriate infectivity assays often hindered the researcher from reaching a coherent conclusion.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = McCabe PM, Pfeiffer P, Van Alfen NK | title = The influence of dsRNA viruses on the biology of plant pathogenic fungi | journal = Trends in Microbiology | volume = 7 | issue = 9 | pages = 377–81 | date = September 1999 | pmid = 10470047 | doi = 10.1016/S0966-842X(99)01568-1 }}</ref> Secondly, mixed infection or unknown numbers of infecting viruses make it very difficult to associate a particular phenotypic change with the investigated virus.
Although most mycoviruses often do not seem to disturb their host’s fitness, this does not necessarily mean they are living unrecognized by their hosts. A neutral co-existence might just be the result of a long co-evolutionary process.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = May RM, Nowak MA | title = Coinfection and the evolution of parasite virulence | journal = Proceedings. Biological Sciences | volume = 261 | issue = 1361 | pages = 209–15 | date = August 1995 | pmid = 7568274 | doi = 10.1098/rspb.1995.0138 | url = http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~ped/people/faculty/publications_nowak/ProcRoySoc95b.pdf }}</ref><ref>Araújo, A., Jansen, A. M., Bouchet, F., Reinhard, K., Ferreira, L. F. (2003). Parasitism, the Diversity of Life, and Paleoparasitology. Memorias do Instituto Oswaldo Cruz, 98 (SUPPL. 1): 5-11.</ref> Accordingly, symptoms may only appear when certain conditions of the virus-fungus-system change and get out of balance. This could be external (environmental) as well as internal (cytoplasmic). It is not known yet why some mycoviruses-fungus-combinations are typically detrimental while others are asymptomatic or even beneficial. Nevertheless, harmful effects of mycoviruses are economically interesting, especially if the fungal host is a phytopathogen and the mycovirus could be exploited as biocontrol agent. The best example is represented by the case of CHV1 and ''C. parasitica''.<ref name="Ghabrial2" /> Other examples of deleterious effects of mycoviruses are the ‘La France’ disease of ''Agaricus biporus''<ref name="Hollings" /><ref name="Ro">{{cite journal | vauthors = Ro HS, Lee NJ, Lee CW, Lee HS | title = Isolation of a novel mycovirus OMIV in Pleurotus ostreatus and its detection using a triple antibody sandwich-ELISA | journal = Journal of Virological Methods | volume = 138 | issue = 1–2 | pages = 24–9 | date = December 2006 | pmid = 16930731 | doi = 10.1016/j.jviromet.2006.07.016 }}</ref> and the mushroom diseases caused by Oyster mushroom spherical virus<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Yu HJ, Lim D, Lee HS | title = Characterization of a novel single-stranded RNA mycovirus in Pleurotus ostreatus | journal = Virology | volume = 314 | issue = 1 | pages = 9–15 | date = September 2003 | pmid = 14517055 | doi = 10.1016/S0042-6822(03)00382-9 }}</ref> and Oyster mushroom isometric virus.<ref name="Ro" />
In summary, the main negative effects of mycoviruses are: * Decreased growth rate<ref name="Mol">{{cite journal | vauthors = Moleleki N, van Heerden SW, Wingfield MJ, Wingfield BD, Preisig O | title = Transfection of Diaporthe perjuncta with Diaporthe RNA virus | journal = Applied and Environmental Microbiology | volume = 69 | issue = 7 | pages = 3952–6 | date = July 2003 | pmid = 12839766 | pmc = 165159 | doi = 10.1128/AEM.69.7.3952-3956.2003 }}</ref> * Lack of sporulation<ref name="Mol" /> * Change of virulence<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Suzaki K, Ikeda KI, Sasaki A, Kanematsu S, Matsumoto N, Yoshida K |date = June 2005 |title=Horizontal transmission and host-virulence attenuation of totivirus in violet root rot fungus ''Helicobasidium mompa''|journal=Journal of General Plant Pathology|volume=71|issue=3|pages=161–168|doi=10.1007/s10327-005-0181-8 }}</ref><ref name="linkinghub.elsevier.com">{{cite journal | vauthors = Özkan S, Coutts RH | title = Aspergillus fumigatus mycovirus causes mild hypervirulent effect on pathogenicity when tested on Galleria mellonella | journal = Fungal Genetics and Biology | volume = 76 | pages = 20–6 | date = March 2015 | pmid = 25626171 | doi = 10.1016/j.fgb.2015.01.003 | url = https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S1087184515000067 }}</ref><ref name=":0"/> * Reduced germination of basidiospores<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Ihrmark K, Stenström E, Stenlid J | title = Double-stranded RNA transmission through basidiospores of Heterobasidion annosum | journal = Mycological Research | volume = 108 | issue = Pt 2 | pages = 149–53 | date = February 2004 | pmid = 15119351 | doi = 10.1017/S0953756203008839 }}</ref>
Hypovirulent phenotypes do not appear to correlate with specific genome features and it seems there is not one particular metabolic pathway causing hypovirulence but several.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Xie J, Wei D, Jiang D, Fu Y, Li G, Ghabrial S, Peng Y | title = Characterization of debilitation-associated mycovirus infecting the plant-pathogenic fungus Sclerotinia sclerotiorum | journal = The Journal of General Virology | volume = 87 | issue = Pt 1 | pages = 241–9 | date = January 2006 | pmid = 16361437 | doi = 10.1099/vir.0.81522-0 }}</ref> In addition to negative effects, beneficial interactions do also occur. Well described examples are the killer phenotypes in yeasts<ref name="Schmitt">{{cite journal | vauthors = Schmitt MJ, Breinig F | title = The viral killer system in yeast: from molecular biology to application | journal = FEMS Microbiology Reviews | volume = 26 | issue = 3 | pages = 257–76 | date = August 2002 | pmid = 12165427 | doi = 10.1016/S0168-6445(02)00099-2 }}</ref> and ''Ustilago''.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Marquina D, Santos A, Peinado JM | title = Biology of killer yeasts | journal = International Microbiology | volume = 5 | issue = 2 | pages = 65–71 | date = June 2002 | pmid = 12180782 | doi = 10.1007/s10123-002-0066-z | url = http://www.im.microbios.org/articles0203/2002/june/03%20Marquina.pdf }}</ref> Killer isolates secrete proteins that are toxic to sensitive cells of the same or closely related species while the producing cells themselves are immune. Most of these toxins degrade the cell membrane.<ref name="Schmitt" /> There are potentially interesting applications of killer isolates in medicine, food industry, and agriculture.<ref name="Dawe" /><ref name="Schmitt" /> A three-part system involving a mycovirus of an endophytic fungus (''Curvularia protuberata'') of the grass ''Dichanthelium lanuginosum'' has been described, which provides a thermal tolerance to the plant, enabling it to inhabit adverse environmental niches.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Márquez LM, Redman RS, Rodriguez RJ, Roossinck MJ | title = A virus in a fungus in a plant: three-way symbiosis required for thermal tolerance | journal = Science | volume = 315 | issue = 5811 | pages = 513–5 | date = January 2007 | pmid = 17255511 | doi = 10.1126/science.1136237 }}</ref> In medically important fungi, an uncharacterized A78 virus of ''[[Aspergillus fumigatus|Aspergillus fugmigatus]]'' causes mild hypervirulent effect on pathogenicity when tested on ''Galleria mellonella'' (Greater wax moth).<ref name="linkinghub.elsevier.com"/> Furthermore, TmPV1, a dsRNA partitivirus, of ''[[Penicillium marneffei|Talaromyces marneffei]] (formerly [[Penicillium marneffei]])'' was found to cause hyperviruelnece phenotype on [[Penicillium marneffei|''Talaromyces marneffei'']] when tested on a mouse model.<ref name=":0" /> These could imply mycoviruses may play important roles in the pathogensis of human pathogenic fungi.

{{Infobox organization | name = Not Dead Yet | image = | size = | alt = <!-- alt text; see [[WP:ALT]] --> | caption = | abbreviation = NDY | motto = | predecessor = | successor = | formation = {{Start date and years ago|1996|04|27}} | extinction = <!-- date of extinction, optional --> | type = group | status = <!-- ad hoc, treaty, foundation, etc --> | purpose = [[Disability rights]]; [[right to life]] | headquarters = [[Rochester, New York]], United States | location = | coords = <!-- Coordinates of location using a coordinates template --> | region_served = | membership = | leader_name = [[Diane Coleman]], founder | key_people = [[Stephen Drake]], spokesperson | website = http://www.notdeadyet.org/ | remarks = }} {{Disability}} '''Not Dead Yet''' (NDY) is a [[United States]] [[disability rights]] group that opposes [[assisted suicide]] and [[euthanasia]] for people with disabilities.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.philly.com/1999-09-23/news/25487953_1_suicide-and-euthanasia-disability-rights-group-disabled-people |first=William R. |last=Macklin |title=Tiny Disability-rights Group Scores At Princeton Not Dead Yet, Built On Opposition To Assisted Suicide And Euthanasia, Gained Notice Protesting Against A Bioethicist. - Philly.com |publisher=Articles.philly.com |date=2001-04-20 |accessdate=2014-02-21}}</ref> Diane Coleman, JD, is the founder and president of this national group. Stephen Drake, a research analyst with NDY, is one of the group's chief spokespersons and contacts for press releases.
The group was founded on April 27, 1996. Its name comes from the film ''[[Monty Python and the Holy Grail]]'', in which [[bubonic plague|plague]] victims are thrown into a cart and hauled off to be buried. A man being given up as a corpse by his family protests that he is "not dead yet!"
In 2004 NDY protested the removal of [[Terri Schiavo]]'s feeding tube.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A19752-2005Apr1.html |title=Schiavo Raised Profile of Disabled |publisher=washingtonpost.com |date= |accessdate=2013-08-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.raggededgemagazine.com/focus/postschiavo0405.html |title=After Terri Schiavo |publisher=Raggededgemagazine.com |date=2005-04-02 |accessdate=2013-08-24}}</ref> They also protested the movie ''[[Million Dollar Baby]]'', in which the injection of an overdose of [[epinephrine]] to euthanize a suicidal [[quadriplegic]] woman is depicted as a rational and compassionate act. The group has been highly critical of utilitarian philosophers such as [[Peter Singer]] of [[Princeton University]]. Coleman has called Professor Singer "the most dangerous man on earth" and asserted that he was advocating genocide.<ref>{{cite news|first=Johann |last=Hari |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/peter-singer-some-people-are-more-equal-than-others-6166342.html |title=Peter Singer: Some people are more equal than others - Profiles - People |publisher=The Independent |date=2004-07-01 |accessdate=2013-08-24}}</ref> In June 2015 NDY organized protests against Singer's position that new-born babies with certain disabilities can morally be killed, which he sees as no different from abortion. The protesters called for Princeton University to dismiss Singer.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2015/jun/16/peter-singer-princeton-bioethics-professor-faces-c/ |first=Jessica |last=Chasmar |title=Peter Singer, Princeton bioethics professor, faces calls for resignation over infanticide support |publisher=Washington Times |date=2015-06-16 |accessdate=2015-06-17}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Care Not Killing]], a similar group in the [[United Kingdom]] *[[Right to die]]
